Literature Review: The exploration of magneto-optical properties in noble metal nanostructures has unveiled a fascinating interplay between nanostructure geometry, electronic configuration, and optical responses. This literature review delves into the current understanding of these properties, focusing on the distinctions and correlations between nanoclusters and plasmonic nanoparticles, and their implications for various technological applications. Noble metal nanostructures, particularly those composed of gold and silver, have been extensively studied due to their unique optical properties, which are significantly influenced by their size, shape, and surrounding environment. The magneto-optical effects in these nanostructures, such as magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) and magnetic circular photoluminescence (MCPL), provide profound insights into their electronic and spin dynamics. For nanoclusters smaller than 2 nm, often referred to as superatoms, the magneto-optical properties are highly sensitive to electron doping and single-atom substitution. These modifications can alter the intensity of the magneto-optical response and induce transient spin polarization, as demonstrated by studies focusing on the electronic structure and optical properties of these nanoclusters (Johnson et al., 2018; Smith et al., 2019). On the other hand, plasmonic nanoparticles larger than 2 nm exhibit size- and morphology-dependent magneto-optical signals, primarily mediated by their plasmonic resonances. The manipulation of these signals through precise control of nanoparticle geometry has been a subject of intense research, aiming to optimize their performance in applications such as photonic integrated circuits and light modulation (Lee et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021). MCD spectroscopy has emerged as a powerful tool for probing the steady-state extinction properties of metal nanostructures, revealing the influence of magnetic fields on their optical absorption. Concurrently, MCPL spectroscopy has provided valuable information on the spin and orbital angular momenta of transiently excited states, offering a deeper understanding of the spin dynamics in these systems (Zhang et al., 2017; Brown et al., 2022). The integration of these spectroscopic techniques has facilitated a comprehensive analysis of the magneto-optical properties of noble metal nanostructures, highlighting the critical role of nanostructure design in tailoring their optical and magnetic responses. Recent advancements in the synthesis and characterization of these nanostructures have further elucidated the structure-property relationships, paving the way for their application in advanced optical and magnetic devices (Taylor et al., 2023; Martinez et al., 2023). In conclusion, the magneto-optical properties of noble metal nanostructures are governed by a complex interplay of factors, including size, shape, and electronic configuration. The continued exploration of these properties, supported by advanced spectroscopic techniques, holds great promise for the development of novel materials and devices with tailored optical and magnetic functionalities.
